result.markdown:
# CS-Bipartite Examples

:::callout-note
Literally exactly the same as using the CS kernel, but all you need to do is
specify `mark_type = "cs_bip"`.
:::

Simulate CS data.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(1)

time <- 10
params_cs_bip_true <- list(
  mu = 2,
  K = 0.5,
  beta = 2,
  beta_edges = 0.5,
  lambda_new = 2,
  # CS_edges = -2.5,
  # CS_triangles = 0.001,
  CS_star.2 = -1,
  CS_star.3 = -3
)

sim <- sim_hawkesNet(
  params = params_cs_bip_true,
  T_end = time,
  mark_type = "cs_bip",
  # formula_rhs = "edges + triangles() + star(c(2,3))",
  formula_rhs = "star(c(2,3))"
)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Simulation took 0.31 seconds"
```


:::
:::


:::callout-note
Need to discuss the `triangles()` parameter. I think the current calculation of
change statistics for triangles is incorrect.
:::


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Bipartite colouring
col_map <- c(
  event = "#377EB8",
  perp  = "#E41A1C"
)
roles <- network::get.vertex.attribute(sim$net, "role")
cols <- col_map[roles]

plot(sim$net, vertex.col = cols)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](examples_cs_bip_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
print(paste("Number of simulated nodes:", nrow(sim$ev$nodes)))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Number of simulated nodes: 84"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
paste("Number of simulated edges:", nrow(sim$ev$edges))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Number of simulated edges: 95"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
paste("Number of simulated events:", sim$events$n)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Number of simulated events: 27"
```


:::
:::


Fit CS data. 

:::callout-tip
Make sure to specify the transformation setting for the CS parameters. 

Ideally will default to correct value, but want to discuss how we are implementing
the arguments, because lowk I like the old way of passing `CS_params` better.
:::


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
params_cs_bip_init <- list(
  mu = 3,
  K = 1,
  beta = 1,
  beta_edges = 1,
  lambda_new = 5,
  # CS_edges = -2.5,
  # CS_triangles = 0.001,
  CS_star.2 = 0,
  CS_star.3 = 0
)

fit <- fit_hawkesNet(
      ev = sim$ev,
      params_init = params_cs_bip_init,
      mark_type = "cs_bip",
      transform = list(CS_star.2 = "none", CS_star.3 = "none"),
      formula_rhs = "star(c(2,3))"
    )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Fitting took 17.54 seconds"
```


:::
:::


Parameter values on the fitted scale:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
unlist(fit$par)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
           mu             K          beta    beta_edges    lambda_new 
 2.4983966518  0.0332980081  0.0001602598  0.8190927271  2.1111173873 
    CS_star.2     CS_star.3 
-1.2626539339  2.0136466943 
```


:::
:::


:::callout-note
Estimates don't look great @_@
:::

Parameter values on the transformed scale:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit$fit$par
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
        mu          K       beta beta_edges lambda_new  CS_star.2  CS_star.3 
 0.9156492 -3.4022577 -8.7387146 -0.1995580  0.7472174 -1.2626539  2.0136467 
```
